journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: On use of equations of motion for two-rotor airship

article-meta.aff: Chair of Control and Systems Engineering, Poznań University of Technology, Poznań, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Wojciech Adamski, Chair of Control and Systems Engineering, Poznań University of Technology, 60-965 Poznań, Poland. Email: wojciech.adamski@put.poznan.pl

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on Parametric Excitation: Applications in science and engineering

abstract.p: In this article, equations of motion for a two-rotor airship are derived. Moreover, the problem of engine applied forces and torques is analysed, and a trajectory generator is described and implemented into a proportional–derivative control scheme. The theoretical considerations are validated by a set of simulation tests. The simulation model takes into account the structure of the drives, namely the two engines placed symmetrically on both sides of the object. The conducted simulations validate the robustness of the controller in the case of unexpected disturbance occurrence.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Airships are flying objects which, thanks to buoyancy, need small amounts of energy to stay in the air. Therefore, they possess a great potential as transport platforms for some applications. One of their most promising function is monitoring open, large or widespread objects, such as construction sites, stadiums, forests, roads and pipelines. That may be one of the reasons why some companies and organizations have recently started interesting projects concerning this subject matter.

Tracking of a given path can be considered as a task of observation of terrestrial objects. The key issue determining the usefulness of such solution is the reliability of path tracking, which must be realized within the assumed error. In practice, the tracking error strongly depends on various factors, for example, the working range of monitoring equipment or external disturbances acting on the system. The latter is usually unpredictable, as airships are functioning in the atmosphere, where they are exposed to chaotic disturbances, e.g. wind gusts. In some cases, those disturbances cannot be levelled even with the maximum value of control signal. All the above mentioned are causing the task of airship path tracking, with error lower than assumed, challenging. During the crucial manoeuring, for example, vertical start and landing, control of the airship with the engines is necessary. On the contrary, control using the tail surfaces has significant impact on the airship behaviour when the relative speed between the machine and the surrounding air is high.
A number of approaches, concerning the control solutions of underactuated vehicles in various environmental conditions, can be distinguished.1–8
In this article, a novel solution is proposed for the airship modelling, original force notation and a trajectory generator.

This study focuses on the two-rotor (fixed on the rotation axes) system. For this type of airship, two degrees of underactuation are seen. First of them, the orientation about Y-axis is self-stabilized at lower speeds through the proper displacement of the centre of buoyancy and the centre of gravity (i.e. the former has to be over the latter). The second degree of underactuation is the position on the Y-axis. The authors approach separates the control algorithm from the actuation system, therefore, the presented method takes into account the values of Y-direction, thus reducing one degree of underactuation.

Additionally, the proposed approach presents the transformation between forces and torques, expressed in the local frames of the engines, into forces and torques acting on the centre of gravity. What is worth mentioning is that only the engines are treated as actuators, while tail surfaces are considered static. In summary, using the proposed modelling method, position of the airship in the three-dimensional space can be stabilized by merely exploiting two rotors.

The control algorithm is realized on the basis of a trajectory generator. The controller is attempting to keep the airship position within the temporary error tunnel (TET). In this study, a simple proportional–derivative (PD) like controller is used, which is in general unappropriated for the given task. It is used only to demonstrate the functionality of the presented concept. Choosing a proper control mechanism is thus beyond the scope of this article. Thanks to the proposed trajectory generator, a harmful effect of temporary (but strong) wind gusts, can be limited.
In the contrast to many publications devoted to this topic,2,3,5,6,9–13 the separation of altitude adjustment and control of motion in horizontal plane are omitted.

If the tail control surfaces are only treated as stabilizers and an assumption is made that the electrical engine is quite lightweight (The weight of the engine proposed for the implementation (AXI 4130/ 20 GOLD LINE) is 409 g. It can generate about 20 N), then it is possible to simplify the implementation of proposed solution in reality. An additional advantage of this control method is the possibility to compensate the overload and prevent crash when rapid helium leak occurs.

This article is organized as follows. Second section deals with the motion equations of the considered airship. Moreover, crucial problems concerning the possible use of the equations are discussed here. The control strategy is presented in ‘Control Scheme’ section. Simulation results for a robotic airship are presented in the fourth section. This article is concluded in the last section.

sec.title: Motion equations
sec.p:
The implemented model corresponds to a real dirigible AS500 (by Airspeed Airships). However, for the purpose of this study, the structure of drives has been modified. After these adjustments, the engines (normally considered as a whole) were moved away symmetrically for a distance of 1 m along Y-axis. As a result, the change of orientation can be achieved by generating different values of engine forces. The tail rotor is not used and the control surfaces are treated as fixed. The side engines are described by fixed points of the airship body. Those points correspond to the applied force vectors FR and FL which lie in the XZ plane, as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Airship model considered in this article.

sec.title: Kinematics
sec.p: In order to describe the airship movement, the Cartesian coordinate system is used. The global reference frame E is placed on the ground and it is treated as the inertial frame. The airship body is described with five moving frames. The basic local frame is placed in the centre of gravity G (centrifugal forces and gravity force are expressed in this frame). Other local frames are: the nose frame N located in the front of the envelope (aerodynamic forces are expressed in the nose frame), the centre of volume frame O (in which buoyancy is described) and the engine frames R and L.

The velocity vector in the frame E is denoted by η·6×1=[φ·θ·ψ·x·y·z·]T, where η1 = [ϕ θ ψ]T stands for the vector of RPY angles (roll, pitch and yaw),14 whereas η2 = [x y z]T represents the position vector. Local velocities in the frame G are collected in the vector v6×1 = [p q r u v w]T, whose elements define the angular velocities about x-, y-, and z axes and the linear velocities along those axes. The relation between these two vectors is expressed as follows15 (1) where RG E denotes the rotation matrix of the frame G in the inertial frame E, while J(η) denotes the transformation matrix between the angular velocities described in the frame G and the global frame E. Furthermore, flexibility of the dirigible is neglected,16 therefore, conversion of velocities between the local frames has the following form17 (2) where ΘA B=XA B·ΦA B denotes a spatial matrix of size 6 × 6, which defines the geometric state of the frame A described in frame B. Components of matrices XA B and φA B are the operators of distance and orientation, respectively. They have the following form (3) (4) where S(B, A) is a skew-symmetric matrix of the position vector between origins of the frames A and B such that x × y = S(x) · y, and RA B is a rotation matrix of A in the B frame.14

sec.title: Dynamics
sec.p: The dynamic equation of an airship must take into account the added mass effect,15,18 which in the canonical form, and is expressed by the modification of matrices M (inertia) and C (Coriolis and centrifugal forces). This modification requires the addition of appropriate real matrices and their counterparts resulting from the fact that the air masses surrounding the airship are moving. The exact description of this phenomenon as well as the estimation methods of obtaining values of added mass matrices are described in Refs. 15, 19 (5) where v·∈6×1 denotes the vector of angular and linear accelerations in the local frame G.

In equation (5), the element Fext represents the influence of the external forces: disturbances, gravity, buoyancy and the aerodynamic forces not included in the added mass effect (e.g. drag coefficient dependent on the material texture). The vector τ ∈ ℝ6×1 denotes the forces and torques generated by the propulsion engines.

According to the assumption about the lack of flexibility, the relation between forces described in the local frames can be represented by the following equation [17] (6) where fA 6×1 and fB 6×1 denote the vectors of torques and forces expressed in the frames A and B, which describe the same rigid body.

The dynamics of the two-rotor airship model (Figure 1) can be expressed by the following equations of motion (7) (8) where V·G=vG+ω×VG means the derivative of global velocities, and VG stands for the derivative of velocities in the local frame. After several modifications, using the matrix form and denoting, in general a × b = S(a) · b, the following relation is obtained (9) Introducing the symbols
and taking into account the added mass in (9), i.e. M = Mrigid + Madded, it can be finally formulated that (10) On the basis of equation (10), it is possible to determine the engine applied forces for the considered two-rotor airship.

sec.title: Engine applied forces
sec.p: In the classical model, components of the vector τ are generated by two engines. Values of the forces generated by the propulsion are calculated on the basis of (6): (11)

The spatial vector of the generalized forces fR and fL defines the torques and forces acting on the fixed points of engines, i.e. f = [NT FT]T, where N is the vector of torques and F the vector of forces.17 Denoting the following relation
from the left-hand side of equation (10) and from the right-hand side of equation (11), it can be written that (12) where Θ(G,R)≡ΘR GandΘ(G,L)≡ΘL G, with τ = τ1 + τ2, Θ(G, R) · fR = τ1, and Θ(G, L) · fL = τ2. Taking into account these relations, it is acquired that (13) (14) After rewriting (10) and (11) in the matrix form the following relation is obtained (15) (16)

In airships, moments generated by engines in their own frames are relatively small. Therefore, an assumption has been made, that if engines apply only forces, then NR = NL = 0. After the application of that assumption, the following relation is obtained (17) (18) One has to solve (17) and (18) to obtain independent engine orientations. (In this case, one engine is considered as two engines, from which one is producing the forces in X-direction and the other in Z-direction.) Afterwards, the following relations are achieved (19) (20) The engines in this study are symmetrically placed with regard to the XZ plane. Thus, when denoting y as the distance between the engine and the XZ plane, it can be written that (21) and consequently (22) (23) Assuming the distances between both the engines and the XZ plane, obtained equations presented below are as follows (24) (25) (26) (27) where FRZ, FRX, FLZ and FLX denote the components of the force applied to the origins of local frames of engines R and L, acting along Z and X axes. The distances xe, ye and ze are absolute values of the engine positions in frame G. In order to guarantee full execution of τ, the following relation must be fulfilled (28) Equations (27) to (28) resulted from the transformation of (11) and constraints arising from the structure of the drives (which can affect only in XZ planes of the frames R and L). From the physical point of view, it enables independent rotation of engines only about their Y-axes. In spite of the underactuation in Y-axis, the object is able to change its orientation by differentiating the forces on right and left engines (τFY in equations (24) to (27)). In summary, X- and Z-axes are directly controlled by changing the orientation of the engines about Y-axis. Error in Y-axis is indirectly alleviated by specific changes in the orientation induced by differences in the thrust.

sec.title: Trajectory generator
sec.p: Moreover, when the maximum curvature of the temporary trajectory exceeds a specified level, which is dependent on the airship manoeuvring capabilities, a transitional point D is generated. The new temporary trajectory is created in a way, that it reaches the main trajectory through point D.

The algorithm will be further explained in detail, based on the example shown in Figure 2. For t = 0, the first temporary trajectory is generated. The beginning of each temporary trajectory is defined by an actual position, orientation and velocity of the object (for each configuration, it is T0, T1, T2 and T3). The beginning of the main trajectory A becomes the end of the first temporary trajectory. When the airship flies through the base of MET, a new temporary trajectory is generated with an end point placed at point B. When MET is exceeded by the airship, a new end point C of the temporary trajectory is created. Point C lies on the last point of the main trajectory for which airship was within MET. Position of the point C determines the progress of the main trajectory realization. When the maximum curvature of the new trajectory is impermissibly high, a transitional point D is created to ensure the necessary smoothness of the trajectory. The new temporary trajectory is also generated when the TET is exceeded. In this case, the end point of the new temporary trajectory remains unchanged.

sec.title: Control scheme
sec.p: It should be reminded that the choice of a particular control algorithm is not a key issue in the proposed solution. Various control algorithms can be applied to ensure the position control or tracking control. In order to present the concept discussed in the previous section, the following simple PD control algorithm is used (29) where KP and KD are diagonal 6 × 6 matrices of the controller gains, while vectors ηd=[ηd1 Tηd2 T]T and η=[η1 Tη2 T]T denote the desired and actual orientations and positions, respectively.
It can be noticed that the control rule does not include the restriction (28) resulting from the inaccuracy of realization of control signals, generated by the algorithm.

sec.title: Control parameters
sec.p: The task of determining the control parameters via the application of genetic algorithm faced some problems which arised from a large number of optimized parameters (in our case, 12). Unfortunately, the obtained sets of parameters, even after several days of calculations, differed from each other. To solve this problem, the limit of function calls was set to 100,000. We have assumed, that this number was sufficient to obtain repetitive results. As a consequence, the following set of parameters of the matrices KP and KD was obtained (30)

sec.title: Movement without disturbances for proper control parameters
sec.p:
The simulation of airship movement was prepared for controller gains given in (30). The trajectory was defined in three-dimensional space with starting point X0 = [50 −100 −70] m and endpoint X1 = [100 100 −30] m. Radius of MET was assumed as δM = 10 m and radius of TET δT = 9 m. The simulation time was set to t = 600 s. For the first-time sample (t0 = 0), airship was placed at the origin of the frame E, and it was oriented the same as the global frame. Moreover, all the velocities were equal to zero. The obtained results are presented in Figures 3 and 4. All figures, which illustrate the movement of the simulated object, represent the position and orientation of the local frame. This frame is represented by a spatial figure in the form of three segments parallel to axes of the local frame G with equal length and a common centre, which represents the origin of the coordinate system. Figure 3.
Position of the airship in three-dimensional (3D) space (left) and XY-plane projection (right). Figure 4.
Position error and local velocities of centre of gravity.

Left-hand side of Figure 5 shows the level of error in control signal realization which is equal to the left-hand side of equation (28). The error increases when the curvature of the trajectory is high. When the object starts to follow very smooth trajectory (enters the MET), oscillations of the error decrease; however, error is not converging to zero. This is a result of an underactuation of the system (i.e. the orientation about the y-axis). In spite of that, as it is shown in Figure 4, the positions errors are in a close neighbourhood of zero. However, this feature significantly limits the maximum speed of the object. The constant error in the x-axis is also the result of a simplified control algorithm. It should be mentioned that through the whole simulation, the error was lower than δM. Right-hand side of Figure 5 depicts the values of the applied forces (24) to (27). The forces are changing smoothly, therefore, physical implementation is possible. The only exceptions are the moments when trajectory generator creates a new temporary trajectory. High peaks around 300 s are generated because of the lack of engine dynamics model. Figure 5.
Level of error in control signal realization (left) and applied forces (right).

The results shown in Figures 3 to 5 demonstrate that proposed solution, described in ‘Motion equation’ section, enabled to effectively control the underactuated objects with complicated dynamics by the use of a simple control algorithm.

sec.title: Movement with disturbances for proper control parameters
sec.p:
To test the robustness of the system against external disturbances, a simple disturbance model in sinusoidal form (variable force acting on the object, which can imitate gust of wind) was implemented. For simulation purposes, the strength of wind was assumed to be fd = 20 N. The duration time was set to td = 4 s and the direction opposite to X-axis of the global coordinate system. The disturbances were acting on the system until the airship was pushed outside MET. The results of those simulations are presented in Figure 6. When airship exceeded MET, new temporary trajectory was generated. The new trajectory was generated by transitional point, in this case, in proximity of a point [70,−70]. Figure 6.
Visualization of a simulation example with wind disturbances in XY-plane projection.

sec.title: Movement without disturbances for incorrect control parameters
sec.p: The following sample set of improper controller gains was used (31)

The results of those simulations are shown in Figure 7. Therefore, the trajectory generator creates the new temporary trajectory, based on the actual state of the object. The new temporary trajectory is smoothing out the control signals (oscillations increases later with higher control signals) and the object is able to continue the flight. Figure 7.
Visualization in 3D space and simulation of XY-plane projection in the case of incorrect parameters.

sec.title: Concluding remarks and future work
sec.p: In this article, applied forces and moments acting on a two-rotor airship are formally derived. A combination of trajectory generator (using MET and TET concepts), a transformation of applied forces and moments and a control algorithm for airships is being tested. The obtained simulation results showed that, using engines only, it is possible to control airships' flight without the use of tail control surfaces. This feature allows some simplification of airships' design and control algorithms. Weight and unreliability of the airship decrease with growing simplicity of its design, which is particularly important for small- and medium-sized blimps.

The proposed approach was verified for a simple PD-like controller. Simulations showed that a small position error in comparison with length of the realized trajectory is achievable. What is worth mentioning is that the level of control signal realization error (Figure 5) decreases with a low-velocity change rate. This phenomenon occurs despite the fact that the control algorithm does not take into account constrain (28). This leads to a conclusion that the described solution seems to be promising, and its physical implementation is possible.

The favourable results of simulation for disturbed motion revealed that appropriate manipulation of the reference trajectory can level the influence of unpredictable gusts. This feature might be important for trajectory tracking in tough environment, example pipeline inspection or forest monitoring.
Simulation of airship motion with incorrect control parameters showed that on using the proposed trajectory generator methodology, the parametric robustness of the whole system increased.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
